title: Costa Rica: Citi Graduates More Than 300 Women Entrepreneurs
summary: San José, Costa Rica - The Citi Foundation is partnering with Junior Achievement and Fundación Mujer in Costa Rica in training low-income women to give them the skills to start their own businesses. The graduation ceremony for the most recent installment of this program was held October 3 at 8:30 a.m. at the San José Palacio Hotel, with the Minister of Economics, Mayi Antillón, in attendance.
tag-1: Costa Rica: Citi Graduates More Than 300 Women Entrepreneurs
tag-3: San José, Costa Rica – The Citi Foundation is partnering with Junior Achievement and Fundación Mujer in Costa Rica in training low-income women to give them the skills to start their own businesses. The graduation ceremony for the most recent installment of this program was held October 3 at 8:30 a.m. at the San José Palacio Hotel, with the Minister of Economics, Mayi Antillón, in attendance.
tag-4: The Mujeres Emprendedoras program has been offered in Costa Rica since 2012 to improve opportunities for women interested in entrepreneurial activities. This year, with the support of Fundación Mujer, more than 300 women completed the program in San Vito de Coto Brus, Heredia, Tres Ríos de Cartago, the southern and eastern zones of San José, and Grecia de Alajuela. The NGO Junior Achievement administers the intensive three-month training.
tag-5: Joint private-public sector programs such as this one, Minister Antillón noted, are particularly effective at empowering women.
tag-6: "Initiatives like the one presented to us today by the Citi Foundation complement the institutional efforts of the Ministry of Economy in overseeing entrepreneurship and SME policy in our country," Antillón explained. "In this case, this program provides substantive support to women who are trying to be financially independent and improve the quality of life of their families. The Fundación Mujer and Junior Achievement partnership also strengthens the sources of support available to women entrepreneurs."
tag-7: Marcelo Gorrini, General Manager of Citi Costa Rica, added: "At Citi, financial inclusion is a key part of our corporate social responsibility plans, and so this project is very important to us. Citi has a Women's Council to support the professional development of its employees, and it offers volunteer opportunities and internships to the program participants who present the best business plans."
tag-8: "The Women Entrepreneurs program is designed to give vulnerable women the capacity to start their own businesses, take risks and make decisions that benefit them and the community at large," commented Junior Achievement's Executive Director, Sonia Cisneros. "This is a unique opportunity for both Junior Achievement and Fundación Mujer to help many women who have been waiting for just such an opportunity."
tag-9: Three hundred women benefited from the program in 2013, a substantial increase from the 200 who completed it last year. In addition to personalized help in developing a business plan, the participants receive seed money for starting their businesses, and Fundación Mujer evaluates some of them for loan applications.

tag-12: Junior Achievement Junior Achievement Costa Rica (JACR) is a non-profit organization affiliated with the international J.A. Worldwide network. Our mission is to inspire and educate young people in subjects such as Financial Education, Entrepreneurism and Employability to enable them to succeed in a global economy. Junior Achievement programs instill in young people a spirit of entrepreneurship that allows them to improve their quality of life. Designated a non-profit institution under Executive Decree No. 24284-J, JACR develops financial education programs that contribute value added by strengthening the modernizing the Costa Rican educational system.
